title: 114_s2477
content:
The "Circuit Court of Appeals Restructuring and Modernization Act" establishes the former ninth circuit, new ninth circuit, and twelfth circuit. SEC. 3 amends the number and composition of circuits in the United States Code, changing the ninth circuit to include California, Guam, Hawaii, and the Northern Mariana Islands, and creating a new twelfth circuit with Alaska, Arizona, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, Oregon, and Washington. SEC. 4 outlines the creation of new judgeships for the ninth circuit court of appeals in California, including 5 additional circuit judges and 2 temporary circuit judges. The section also specifies that the first 2 vacancies occurring 10 years after the appointment of temporary judges will not be filled. This section takes effect upon the enactment of the Act. SEC. 5 amends the table in title 28, United States Code, by adjusting the number of circuit judges for the ninth and twelfth circuits. SEC. 6 updates the table with the locations of circuit courts for the ninth and twelfth circuits. The Twelfth Circuit's headquarters will be located in Phoenix, Arizona. Circuit judges from the former ninth circuit will be assigned to either the new ninth circuit or the twelfth circuit based on their official duty station. Senior judges will have the option to choose their assignment. SEC. 9. Senior judges from the former ninth circuit can choose to be assigned to the new ninth circuit or the twelfth circuit. They must notify the Director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts of their decision. SEC. 10. The seniority of judges assigned or electing to be assigned will be based on their commission date in the former ninth circuit. SEC. 11. Applies to cases. On the day before the effective date of this Act, appeals or proceedings filed with the former ninth circuit will continue as if this Act had not been enacted. If not yet decided, cases will be transferred to the appropriate court and proceed as if this Act was in effect when the appeal was initiated. If a petition for rehearing en banc is pending on or after the effective date of this Act, it will be considered by the court of appeals as if the appeal had been filed in that court. SEC. 12 allows for temporary assignment of circuit judges between the Ninth and Twelfth Circuits, while SEC. 13 allows for temporary assignment of district judges among circuits. Section 292 of title 28, United States Code, allows for the temporary assignment of district judges between the Ninth and Twelfth Circuits in the public interest. The chief judges of the respective circuits can designate and assign judges as needed for the business of the courts. Section 292 of title 28, United States Code allows for the temporary assignment of district judges between the Ninth and Twelfth Circuits as needed for the business of the courts. District judges within the Twelfth Circuit can be designated to sit on the Court of Appeals of the Ninth Circuit or hold a district court in any district within the Ninth Circuit. The designation or assignment must comply with the rules or orders of the respective circuit. SEC. 14. ADMINISTRATION.

The court of appeals for the ninth circuit may take administrative actions to carry out this Act and its amendments. It will cease to exist for administrative purposes 2 years after the enactment of this Act.

SEC. 15. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

Sums necessary to implement this Act, including funds for court facilities, are authorized to be appropriated.

SEC. 16. EFFECTIVE DATE.

This Act and its amendments will take effect 1 year after enactment, except as provided in section 4(c).
